page.title: Getting Started
page.p:
To begin using this tutorial, there are a few steps to set up your environment: Open up a command-line interface and run the following command:
$ git clone ...

This will create a new folder called "untie" in your current directory. Move into this folder:
$ cd untie

And then run the following line:
$ source setup

Now, rather than seeing a "$" before every command, you'll see your current directory like so:
~/untie$ echo hello hello

Our convention, as you might have gathered, is that things that are happening in the terminal will be put in blue code blocks. Within these, bold text indicates text you are supposed to type, and non-bold text is meant to be outputted on its own. In addition, red, italicised text will be author's commentary and won't actually appear in your terminal.

A word now about the organisation of this tutorial: Both the basic and advanced sections are centred around a set of guided tasks, where you will e.g. refactor a programming project, write an alarm clock script, batch resize images, and more, and the bash skills necessary for each of these will be explained along the way. A quick summary of the intent of each of the sections:
Basic tutorial: This is meant as a decent, standalone introduction to bash for the total beginner. Along the way, we will discuss also system calls, some file formats, and a few less-used bash commands, so it should be informative for someone who is not entirely a beginner as well.
Advanced tutorial: This is built on the foundation of the basic tutorial and covers advanced command usage and pipelines as well as some of the subtleties arising from an understanding of bash and, indeed, Linux internals.
Reference: This section contains a summary of all the bash commands and language features used in this tutorial, as well as brief tutorials explaining certain select programs (or certain features of these programs) that the author deemed very useful and for which a pre-existing online tutorial was not easily located.
